sectionObjective: Talk about hobbies and free time activities/Discuss trying new things

sectionSkills.skillTitle: present perfect progressive; had to/needed to

textContents.paragraphTitle: My six months of trying new things
paragraphContents: I've never been the kind of person who does lots of exciting things in their free time. Paragliding, swimming with dolphins, climbing Mount Everest - not me! My idea of danger is to sit on the couch and watch the latest crime series on TV. The closest I get to nature is when I like my friends' cat pictures on social media. As for climbing Himalayan mountains - forget it! I'd rather climb the stairs to bed.

But at one point toward the end of last year, I started to feel that my life was becoming a little... well... boring. I needed to take up a hobby. But which one? There are so many things out there - how do you know what you will enjoy? So I decided to spend the first six months of this year trying out a new hobby each month. I was a complete beginner at every activity I tried.

The first thing I learned was that no flies are harmed in fly fishing. You make a pretty, artificial fly and attach it to a hook on a fishing line. Then you throw the line on the water. When a fish takes a bite, you... oh, I don't know. I did NOT do well at this. One month: lots of badly made flies, and ZERO fish (apart from the ones I got at the fish and fries place on my way home).
Why does anyone do this? Is this really a hobby? After a whole four weeks of attaching little squares of paper from around the world into a big book with blank pages, I still have no idea.

This one really surprised me. I'm actually good at it! I joined a club, and I didn't need to spend a lot of time practicing before I started winning games. After only a month, I was already one of the best players in the group. I really can't believe it. Maybe there’s a chance for me to get in shape after all.

Surely all I had to do was keep some flying insects in a box? What could possibly go wrong? About a hundred bee stings later, I realized that a lot can go wrong and beekeeping is a serious (and sometimes painful) business. I think I'll just get my honey from the grocery store in future.

The ukulele is like a very small guitar. It has four strings. It makes you look like a giant when you play it. I really enjoyed this. I didn't have to be in great shape. It wasn't dangerous and it wasn't painful. And at the end of the month, I could play Rivers of Babylon all the way through. If that isn't success, I don't know what is!

Ouch! I thought yoga was relaxing. I didn't realize I had to be super athletic and flexible. After one month of downward dogs and (falling over!) tree poses, I learned some very important things about me: I am not very athletic. I am not very flexible. I do not like yoga.

sets.exerciseInstruction: Work in pairs. When was the last time you:
Read the first two paragraphs of My six months of trying new things. Then complete the summary with a word in the box.
Read the rest of the article. Match the activities (1–6) with Candie’s experiences (a–f ).

exercises.exerciseQuestion: She was able to complete a whole song.
She was surprised by how good she was at this activity.
She learned that she is not able to do this kind of thing well because she isn’t athletic.
She didn’t understand why this is a popular hobby.

sets.exerciseInstruction: Read again. Fill in the blanks in the article (1–6) with the sentences (a–f ).
Look at the highlighted words and phrases. What do the capital letters, punctuation and word choice tell us about the article’s tone?
Work in pairs. If you had to choose one of these activities to take up for a month, which would you choose? Why? Tell your partner.
